fields.label: Please take some time to read about this surgery as proposed by your treating Specialist, and sign at the end of the document to indicate your consent. If you have any questions do not hesitate to ask.

groups.label: • Skin graft surgery involves using skin from another area of the body to restore skin coverage in area(s) of concern. Skin grafts help wounds heal that otherwise would not heal adequately.

• Alternative forms of care consist of not undergoing surgery. Some minor wounds may heal without surgery. In other situations, different forms of treatment such as the transfer of skin and other composite pieces of tissue may be preferable to skin grafts.

Every surgical procedure involves a certain amount of risk and it is important that you understand the risks involved with skin graft surgery. An individual’s choice to undergo a surgical procedure is based on the comparison of the risk to potential benefit. Although the majority of patients do not experience the following complications, you should discuss each of them with your treating Specialist to make sure you understand all possible consequences of skin graft surgery.
• Follow all physician instructions carefully; this is essential for the success of your outcome.

Informed-consent documents are used to communicate information about the proposed surgical treatment of a disease or condition along with disclosure of risks and alternative forms of treatment(s). The informed-consent process attempts to define principles of risk disclosure that should generally meet the needs of most patients in most circumstances.
and such assistants as may be selected to perform the following procedure(s):
SKIN GRAFT SURGERY

Patient’s name:
Date

fields.label: • Skin graft surgery involves using skin from another area of the body to restore skin coverage in area(s) of concern. Skin grafts help wounds heal that otherwise would not heal adequately.
• Skin grafts are useful in situations where there is adequate subcutaneous tissues present to provide support and blood supply for the skin graft.

groups.label: • Skin graft is an effective way to assist wound healing when there has been a loss of skin due to conditions that involve disease, injuries including burns, or surgical removal of skin cancer. Some wounds may be too complex to heal without other more involved reconstructive techniques.

• Risks and potential complications are associated with alternative forms of treatment. Although wounds can heal spontaneously, there may be increased risk of unsatisfactory result, scarring, and functional impairment.
Bleeding
• It is possible, though unusual, to experience a bleeding episode during or after surgery.
• Should post-operative bleeding occur, it may require emergency treatment to drain accumulated blood (hematoma).

• Do not take any aspirin or anti-inflammatory medications for ten days before surgery, as this may increase the risk of bleeding. Non-prescription “herbs” and dietary supplements can increase the risk of surgical bleeding.
Infection
• Infections after skin graft surgery may occur. Additional treatment may be required.
• There is the possibility of skin graft failure or scarring from an infection. Should an infection occur, treatment including antibiotics or additional surgery may be necessary.
Itching
• Itching is a common complaint in both the skin graft donor location and the recipient location.
• Itching may be a chronic complaint.
• Graft abrasion may occur from scratching.
Inability to heal

• Skin grafts require adequate blood supply for survival. Areas of the body where there is inadequate blood supply due to injury, disease states, or the effect of radiation therapy, may not be capable of providing adequate blood supply for skin graft survival.
• Skin grafts are also vulnerable to loss in disease situations where there is a propensity for chronic swelling or vascular insufficiency disorders.
• Some wounds may be to the extent and severity that skin grafts cannot produce closure of the wound and healing. More involved reconstructive surgical procedures may be necessary.
Smokers have a greater risk of skin loss and wound healing complications.
Skin scarring
• Excessive scarring can occur. In rare cases, abnormal scars may result.
• Scars may be unattractive and of different colour than surrounding skin.
• Scarring may limit joint and extremity function.
• Special compressive garments may be needed to help control scarring. Additional treatments including surgery may be necessary to treat abnormal scarring.
Skin sensation
• Diminished (or loss) of skin sensation in the donor location for the graft as well as the location where the graft is placed may occur and not totally resolve after skin graft surgery.
• Skin grafts generally do not regain normal skin sensation.
• Injuries may occur secondary to this lack of sensation if the skin graft is subjected to excessive heat, cold, or physical force.
• Skin grafts placed in areas of decreased sensation are prone to injury and loss.
• Care must be given to avoid injury to these areas or complications may occur.
Skin contour irregularities
• Contour irregularities and depressions may occur after skin graft surgery.
• Visible and palpable wrinkling of skin can occur.
Delayed healing

• Scarring and inadequate healing may occur in the location where the skin graft is taken for transfer to other parts of the body. Healing of the donor area may take unacceptably long periods of time. The donor area once healed may be prone to abrasions. The skin graft may heal abnormally or slowly.
Colour change

• Skin grafts and the skin graft donor location can undergo changes in colour. It is possible to have these areas be either darker or lighter than surrounding skin. These changes can be permanent. Additionally, these areas may have exaggerated responses with changes in skin colour to hot or cold temperatures.
Inability to restore function

• In some situations, skin grafts cannot restore the normal function of intact skin or undamaged deeper structures. Although it may be possible to produce healing with a skin graft, there can be a loss of function. Additional treatment and surgery may be necessary.
Surgical anaesthesia
• Both local and general anaesthesia involve risk. There is the possibility of complications, injury, and even death from all forms of surgical anaesthesia or sedation.
Damage to associated structures
• Structures such as nerves, blood vessels, and soft tissues may be damaged during surgery.
Allergic reactions

• In rare cases, local allergies to tape, suture material, or topical preparations have been reported. Systemic reactions, which are more serious, may result from drugs used during surgery and prescription medicines. Allergic reactions may require additional treatment.
Skin cancer in skin grafts
• Skin cancer can rarely occur in skin grafts.
Pain
• Chronic pain may occur very infrequently from nerves becoming trapped in scar tissue or from other causes after skin graft surgery.
Lack of graft durability
• Skin grafts do not have the normal padding and durability of normal, undamaged skin.
• Skin grafts lack the normal ability of skin to resist ordinary abrasions and injuries.
Travel Plans:

• Any surgery holds the risk of complications that may delay healing and your return to normal life. Please let the surgeon know of any travel plans, important commitments already scheduled or planned, or time demands that are important to you, so that appropriate timing of surgery can occur.
• There are no guarantees that you will be able to resume all activities in the desired timeframe.
• Allow at least 10-14 days to travel via airplane.
Additional Surgery Necessary:

Should complications occur, additional surgery or other treatments may be necessary. Even though risks and complications occur infrequently, the risks cited are particularly associated with skin graft surgery. Other complications and risks can occur but are even more uncommon. The practice of medicine and surgery is not an exact science. Although good results are expected, there is no guarantee or warranty expressed or implied on the results that may be obtained.
It is important that surgical incisions are not subjected to excessive force, swelling, abrasion, or motion during the time of healing.
• Personal and vocational activity needs to be restricted.
• Protective dressings and drains should not be removed unless instructed by your plastic surgeon. Successful post-operative function depends on both surgery and subsequent care.
• It is important that you participate in follow-up care to promote your recovery after surgery.

However, every patient is unique and informed-consent documents should not be considered all-inclusive in defining other methods of care and risks encountered when medical care is reasonable and directed at obtaining appropriate results. Your plastic surgeon may provide you with additional or different information, which is based on all the facts in your particular case and the state of medical knowledge. Informed-consent documents are not intended to define or serve as the standard of medical care. Standards of medical care are determined on the basis of all of the facts involved in an individual case and are subject to change as scientific knowledge and technology advance and as practice patterns evolve.
• My condition
• The nature and purpose of procedure(s)
• Complications (problems) that may arise

I have received answers to all my questions about my condition, the procedure(s), possible alternatives, possible complications, and the risks. I accept the risk of substantial and serious harm, if any, with hope to better my condition from the procedures(s).
I also understand that problem(s) and complications may occur even when the best care, judgement, and skill are used.

I know that any time a person has an operation or other medical procedures, there are risks of serious injury or even death. No guarantees have been promised to me from this procedure(s) or from the anaesthesia.

I understand that image(s) or video footage may be recorded as part of and during my procedure and that these image(s) or video(s) will assist the doctor to provide the appropriate treatment. It may also be used for research and educational purposes.
I ACCEPT THE STATEMENTS ABOVE AND THE RISKS INVOLVED.
Patient’s signature:
Witness signature:

It is important that surgical incisions are not subjected to excessive force, swelling, abrasion, or motion during the time of healing.
• Personal and vocational activity needs to be restricted.
• Protective dressings and drains should not be removed unless instructed by your plastic surgeon. Successful post-operative function depends on both surgery and subsequent care.
• It is important that you participate in follow-up care to promote your recovery after surgery.

However, every patient is unique and informed-consent documents should not be considered all-inclusive in defining other methods of care and risks encountered when medical care is reasonable and directed at obtaining appropriate results. Your plastic surgeon may provide you with additional or different information, which is based on all the facts in your particular case and the state of medical knowledge. Informed-consent documents are not intended to define or serve as the standard of medical care. Standards of medical care are determined on the basis of all of the facts involved in an individual case and are subject to change as scientific knowledge and technology advance and as practice patterns evolve.

I also understand that problem(s) and complications may occur even when the best care, judgement, and skill are used.

I know that any time a person has an operation or other medical procedures, there are risks of serious injury or even death. No guarantees have been promised to me from this procedure(s) or from the anaesthesia.

I understand that image(s) or video footage may be recorded as part of and during my procedure and that these image(s) or video(s) will assist the doctor to provide the appropriate treatment. It may also be used for research and educational purposes.

field_1_2_0.label: • Skin graft is an effective way to assist wound healing when there has been a loss of skin due to conditions that involve disease, injuries including burns, or surgical removal of skin cancer. Some wounds may be too complex to heal without other more involved reconstructive techniques.

field_2_0_0.label: • Alternative forms of care consist of not undergoing surgery. Some minor wounds may heal without surgery. In other situations, different forms of treatment such as the transfer of skin and other composite pieces of tissue may be preferable to skin grafts.

field_2_1_0.label: • Risks and potential complications are associated with alternative forms of treatment. Although wounds can heal spontaneously, there may be increased risk of unsatisfactory result, scarring, and functional impairment.

field_3_0_0.label: Every surgical procedure involves a certain amount of risk and it is important that you understand the risks involved with skin graft surgery. An individual’s choice to undergo a surgical procedure is based on the comparison of the risk to potential benefit. Although the majority of patients do not experience the following complications, you should discuss each of them with your treating Specialist to make sure you understand all possible consequences of skin graft surgery.

field_3_2_0.label: • It is possible, though unusual, to experience a bleeding episode during or after surgery.

field_3_3_0.label: • Should post-operative bleeding occur, it may require emergency treatment to drain accumulated blood (hematoma).

field_3_4_0.label: • Do not take any aspirin or anti-inflammatory medications for ten days before surgery, as this may increase the risk of bleeding. Non-prescription “herbs” and dietary supplements can increase the risk of surgical bleeding.

field_3_6_0.label: • Infections after skin graft surgery may occur. Additional treatment may be required.

field_3_7_0.label: • There is the possibility of skin graft failure or scarring from an infection. Should an infection occur, treatment including antibiotics or additional surgery may be necessary.

field_3_9_0.label: • Itching is a common complaint in both the skin graft donor location and the recipient location.

field_3_10_0.label: • Itching may be a chronic complaint.

field_3_11_0.label: • Graft abrasion may occur from scratching.

field_3_13_0.label: • Skin grafts require adequate blood supply for survival. Areas of the body where there is inadequate blood supply due to injury, disease states, or the effect of radiation therapy, may not be capable of providing adequate blood supply for skin graft survival.

field_3_14_0.label: • Skin grafts are also vulnerable to loss in disease situations where there is a propensity for chronic swelling or vascular insufficiency disorders.

field_3_15_0.label: • Some wounds may be to the extent and severity that skin grafts cannot produce closure of the wound and healing. More involved reconstructive surgical procedures may be necessary.

field_3_16_0.label: Smokers have a greater risk of skin loss and wound healing complications.

field_3_18_0.label: • Excessive scarring can occur. In rare cases, abnormal scars may result.

field_3_19_0.label: • Scars may be unattractive and of different colour than surrounding skin.

field_3_20_0.label: • Scarring may limit joint and extremity function.

field_3_21_0.label: • Special compressive garments may be needed to help control scarring. Additional treatments including surgery may be necessary to treat abnormal scarring.

field_3_23_0.label: • Diminished (or loss) of skin sensation in the donor location for the graft as well as the location where the graft is placed may occur and not totally resolve after skin graft surgery.

field_3_24_0.label: • Skin grafts generally do not regain normal skin sensation.

field_3_25_0.label: • Injuries may occur secondary to this lack of sensation if the skin graft is subjected to excessive heat, cold, or physical force.

field_3_26_0.label: • Skin grafts placed in areas of decreased sensation are prone to injury and loss.

field_3_27_0.label: • Care must be given to avoid injury to these areas or complications may occur.

field_3_29_0.label: • Contour irregularities and depressions may occur after skin graft surgery.

field_3_30_0.label: • Visible and palpable wrinkling of skin can occur.

field_3_32_0.label: • Scarring and inadequate healing may occur in the location where the skin graft is taken for transfer to other parts of the body. Healing of the donor area may take unacceptably long periods of time. The donor area once healed may be prone to abrasions. The skin graft may heal abnormally or slowly.

field_3_34_0.label: • Skin grafts and the skin graft donor location can undergo changes in colour. It is possible to have these areas be either darker or lighter than surrounding skin. These changes can be permanent. Additionally, these areas may have exaggerated responses with changes in skin colour to hot or cold temperatures.

field_3_36_0.label: • In some situations, skin grafts cannot restore the normal function of intact skin or undamaged deeper structures. Although it may be possible to produce healing with a skin graft, there can be a loss of function. Additional treatment and surgery may be necessary.

field_3_38_0.label: • Both local and general anaesthesia involve risk. There is the possibility of complications, injury, and even death from all forms of surgical anaesthesia or sedation.

field_3_40_0.label: • Structures such as nerves, blood vessels, and soft tissues may be damaged during surgery.

field_3_42_0.label: • In rare cases, local allergies to tape, suture material, or topical preparations have been reported. Systemic reactions, which are more serious, may result from drugs used during surgery and prescription medicines. Allergic reactions may require additional treatment.

field_3_44_0.label: • Skin cancer can rarely occur in skin grafts.

field_3_46_0.label: • Chronic pain may occur very infrequently from nerves becoming trapped in scar tissue or from other causes after skin graft surgery.

field_3_48_0.label: • Skin grafts do not have the normal padding and durability of normal, undamaged skin.

field_3_49_0.label: • Skin grafts lack the normal ability of skin to resist ordinary abrasions and injuries.

field_3_51_0.label: • Any surgery holds the risk of complications that may delay healing and your return to normal life. Please let the surgeon know of any travel plans, important commitments already scheduled or planned, or time demands that are important to you, so that appropriate timing of surgery can occur.

field_3_52_0.label: • There are no guarantees that you will be able to resume all activities in the desired timeframe.

field_3_53_0.label: • Allow at least 10-14 days to travel via airplane.

field_3_55_0.label: Should complications occur, additional surgery or other treatments may be necessary. Even though risks and complications occur infrequently, the risks cited are particularly associated with skin graft surgery. Other complications and risks can occur but are even more uncommon. The practice of medicine and surgery is not an exact science. Although good results are expected, there is no guarantee or warranty expressed or implied on the results that may be obtained.

field_4_0_0.label: • Follow all physician instructions carefully; this is essential for the success of your outcome.

field_4_1_0.label: It is important that surgical incisions are not subjected to excessive force, swelling, abrasion, or motion during the time of healing.

field_4_2_0.label: • Personal and vocational activity needs to be restricted.

field_4_3_0.label: • Protective dressings and drains should not be removed unless instructed by your plastic surgeon. Successful post-operative function depends on both surgery and subsequent care.

field_4_4_0.label: • It is important that you participate in follow-up care to promote your recovery after surgery.

field_5_0_0.label: Informed-consent documents are used to communicate information about the proposed surgical treatment of a disease or condition along with disclosure of risks and alternative forms of treatment(s). The informed-consent process attempts to define principles of risk disclosure that should generally meet the needs of most patients in most circumstances.

field_5_1_0.label: However, every patient is unique and informed-consent documents should not be considered all-inclusive in defining other methods of care and risks encountered when medical care is reasonable and directed at obtaining appropriate results. Your plastic surgeon may provide you with additional or different information, which is based on all the facts in your particular case and the state of medical knowledge. Informed-consent documents are not intended to define or serve as the standard of medical care. Standards of medical care are determined on the basis of all of the facts involved in an individual case and are subject to change as scientific knowledge and technology advance and as practice patterns evolve.
